bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Merritte W. Ireland, May 14, 1941

div1.p: Hench is grateful to Ireland for his interest in the preservation of Camp Lazear and Building No. 1. Hench and Moran will make inquiries into the cost of the preservation.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Merritte W. Ireland, May 14, 1941
div1.opener:
Y F.
May 14, 1941
General Merritt W. Ireland
1870 Wyoming Avenue, N. W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Ireland:
div1.p:
It was indeed a great privilege and honor to have had such a delightful
lunch with you and General Kean. I am very grateful for your time and willingness to
listen to my story of the rediscovery of the lost Camp Lazear and I was greatly en-
couraged by your feeling that we should at least make an attempt to preserve Camp
Lazear and Building No. 1. I shall be only too grateful for any advice that you can
give me in the matter and for the names of those who might be interested. I have
never taken on such a job before and am not too certain as to how to go about it.

It seems to me that before we form our little memorial committee and
ask for help we should have a pretty definite knowledge of just what help we need.
Therefore, before calling on anyone further I am going to write to an engineer and
contractor in Cuba who I think is honest (and who will be under the scrutiny of Moran,
who is kindly acting as my agent in Havana) to get a pretty good idea just how much
a little suitable building would cost--whether it would be $15,000 or $25,000. Also
how much it would cost to move the building a mile to the proposed site near the Mili-
tary Hospital. I believe in the meantime you were going to tell General Cummings a
little synopsis of our findings and ask for his suggestions. Please let me assure
you again that I have absolutely no ulterior motive. I merely wish to see the sites
properly preserved and hate to see them lost again, this time permanently. I have
already spent not a little money on the investigation and I am prepared to contribute
the first thousand dollars toward the fund out of my own pocket.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
